results.title: Trump Floats an Election Delay, and Republicans Shoot It Down

results.title: Trump Attacks an Election He Is at Risk of Losing

results.title: Why Trump Has No Power to Delay the 2020 Election
results.abstract: We answer some key questions about holding elections in a crisis. And no, the president cannot cancel an election on his own.

multimedia.caption: The November general election date is set by federal law, and to change it would require legislation enacted by Congress, signed by the president and subject to challenge in the courts.

results.title: Emmys: Jeremy Pope Is Glad He Took a Chance on ‘Hollywood’
results.abstract: The Broadway veteran received an Emmy nomination for his TV debut, in the revisionist Netflix series. “I cried this morning,” he said. “It’s like feeling seen from a new group of people.”

multimedia.caption: Jeremy Pope received his first Emmy nomination on Tuesday, for best actor in a limited series or movie for Netflix’s “Hollywood.”

results.title: Old Vaccines May Stop the Coronavirus, Study Hints. Scientists Are Skeptical.
results.abstract: Certain vaccines may provide broad protection against infections. But new research doesn’t prove these vaccines can turn back the coronavirus, experts said.

multimedia.caption: A medical worker administering a flu vaccine to a woman in Asuncion, Paraguay. Some vaccines seem to protect against infections they were never intended to target.

results.title: Too Much Mars? Let’s Discuss Other Worlds
results.abstract: Two veteran space journalists discuss why so much attention and budget seems to be directed to the red planet.
results.byline: By Rebecca Boyle and David W. Brown

results.title: The Pandemic’s Toll on Children With Special Needs and Their Parents
results.abstract: Missing social contacts and altered routines, disturbed sleep and eating habits can be particularly intense for the kids with developmental challenges.

results.title: Older Children Spread the Coronavirus Just as Much as Adults, Large Study Finds
results.abstract: The study of nearly 65,000 people in South Korea suggests that school reopenings will trigger more outbreaks.

multimedia.caption: Students, parents and teachers of Cheondong Elementary School in Daejeon, South Korea, got tested in early July after two students were found to be infected with the virus.
